title: The Legacy of Sir Andreas Whittam Smith: Innovator in Journalism
summary: Sir Andreas Whittam Smith, co-founder of The Independent newspaper, has died at 88, as announced by his family. A former financial journalist at The Daily Telegraph, he launched The Independent in 1986 with colleagues Stephen Glover and Matthew Symonds, marking a significant moment in British media by establishing the first major newspaper without a permanent political allegiance. Described as a radical and pioneer by Amol Rajan, a former editor, Sir Andreas is credited with transforming British journalism. Beyond his newspaper work, he held key public roles, including serving as First Estates Church Commissioner from 2002 to 2017, managing the Church of England's investments, and as President of the British Board of Film Classification, where he made controversial decisions like approving a remake of Lolita. He was recognized with honors such as being made a Commander of the British Empire in 2002 and knighted in 2015 for his service to the Church of England. The article highlights his multifaceted career and lasting impact on media and society.

background_read: Sir Andreas Whittam Smith was a prominent British journalist born in the 20th century, known for co-founding The Independent in 1986, which challenged traditional newspaper biases by not aligning with any political party. He had a diverse career, working at newspapers like the Financial Times and The Guardian, and held significant public service roles, including managing the Church of England's investments and rating films. His work reflects the changes in British media during the Thatcher era, and he was honored with knighthood for his contributions. Understanding his life helps illustrate the evolution of journalism and public service in the UK.
